bug.short_desc: [Undo] API request: org.eclipse.ui.internal.ide.undo.ResourceDescription

long_desc.thetext:
I20061129-1340
To support undo for file operations in the Package Explorer, we need the functionality of org.eclipse.ui.internal.ide.undo.ResourceDescription. Could this class be promoted to API?
I've copied the package for now (to avoid referencing internal code). We need more low-level operations than what's currently in org.eclipse.ui.ide.undo, because we must let jdt.core do the actual modifications and because our actions are refactorings with participants, which must adhere to the ltk.core.refactoring undo story.
This should be resolved before the API freeze.
cc'ing Tod. I am on leave right now, but saw this go by. Will be back in mid-Feb...when is API freeze? I can try to look at this before my return if necessary.
Susan: I was going to take a look at this sometime this week. Shall I hold off?
Kim please have a look at this

Fix in HEAD. In order to avoid exposing the subclasses or a "parent" setter I've had to introduce a new baseclass called AbstractResourceDescription in the internal package. It contains all of the implementation that was in the original ResourceDescription except for the statics and the public baseclass now contains nothing but abstract methods and the statics.
Thanks, works great.
Verified in source in I20070206-0010

bug.short_desc: XML Declaration Syntax Error

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Create an xhtml-file with an XML declaration at the beginning of the file:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?>
Choose .php as file extension.
2. Open the file with PHP IDE's PHP Edior.
3. The editor generates syntax errors:
unexpected 'version' unexpected 'encoding'
More information:
This needs to be fixed for PHP files.

This is not a bug, the php workaround is the following: <?php echo '<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>';?>
one should not use <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> to set the encoding of the document.
moreover one could use: <?='<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>'?>

(In reply to comment #2) > This is not a bug, > the php workaround is the following: > <?php echo '<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?>';?>
Sorry, but I think this is a bug. I know that workarounds are possible. But workarounds presuppose bugs.
I think it should be possible to have PHP processing instructions in valid XHTML documents or XML documents of any document type for that matter.
> one should not use <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> to set the encoding > of the document.
Maybe, but and XML preamble should still be legal in an XML document.

Tellio, Thank you for your response, but we develop PHP editor and according to the PHP language the statement: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?> is invalid. the PHP parser yields "parse error" message.
Sorry but it won't be fixed.

(In reply to comment #5)
> Thank you for your response, but we develop PHP editor and according to the PHP > language the statement: <?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8" ?> > is invalid. the PHP parser yields "parse error" message. > > Sorry but it won't be fixed.
That is most unfortunate. I always considered PHP as a language embedded in XML/SGML documents with the use of processing instructions, I guess I was wrong.
I think it should be easy to implement though and one could than even validate such XML-documents against a DTD or schema or embed other processing instructions like <?tex.
Thanks and regards, Horst
the requested should be written as php expects

bug.short_desc: Creation of "Deployable plug-ins with AspectJ support" fails

long_desc.thetext:
I have a plugin that needs refers to 37 .jars and needs to to weave aspects into 5 of them. Things compile and work all fine when starting and testing the plugin using the runtime workbench.
However, trying to export the plugin and wrap it up as a deployable plugin fails. The compilation (using iajc) triggered by the export fails with multiple error messages, each stating that it could not verify whether some type implements some interface. Strange enough, a .zip file is created but the included jars have no aspects woven into them and hence fail at runtime. As a side-effect of the build triggered by the export the build.xml is deleted every time.
So, the export as deployable plugins with AspectJ support does not seem to work at all.
I can supply a (rather large, though) project showing the described errors.
The same problem exists with AJDT 1.4.1 & eclipse 3.2.1 and AJDT 1.5 & eclipse 3.3M3.
Michael

OK, there are a few different issues here. Not knowing what's in your JARs/projects and what weaving is going on, all I can do is recreate the key elements as described and tell you what I've found & how I can make the fundamentals work.
I set up a Hello World plug-in project, based on the example that simply adds a menu item that displays a message dialog when activated. I added a line that creates an instance of a class "UtilityClass", which is in "utility.jar". This JAR is in the root of the project directory structure, and has been added both to the project's Aspect Path and its Java Build Path.
I then added an aspect to the project, advising "UtilityClass" to display another message dialog when the constructor is called. Running the project as an Eclipse application and using the plugin, shows that the second (woven) dialog is there.
Now the tricky part.
1. Exporting the plugin as "Deployable plug-ins and fragments with AspectJ support" I get a set of errors about build.xml in an error dialog summarised as "Problems during export". However, this can be fixed by opening plugin.xml and adding utility.jar to the plug-in classpath, on the runtime tab. The Plugin now exports without failure (actually I had to set -XX:MaxPermSize=128m for my Eclipse instance to avoid an out of memory problem, but that may or may not apply to you). I'd guess your "could not verify whether some type implements some interface" could be solved similarly.
2. AFAIK, the generated build.xml file should be deleted, as it is a temporary file, with the permanent, pertinent information residing in build.properties.
3. In the working, error free zip file, the following is to be expected:
- the class files for each of the source files (.java or .aj) in your plug-in project. - the utility.jar as added to the classpath
You won't get the woven versions of the classes in utility.jar, as there are no corresponding source files. You can, however, do the following:
- specify an outjar for your project, in the project properties, and add it to the classpath, in the "Runtime" tab of the plugin.xml editor
- also add the origin JAR ("utility.jar"), if the woven versions of the classes from this JAR depend on other classes which have not had any aspects woven in to them. Add it below the outjar.
- on the plugin.xml "Build" tab, check the two JARs under "Binary Build"
If you export as before now, you should get your plugin using the woven versions of the classes from the outjar and resolving any other classes from the original JAR.
Bit of a kerfuffle, I know, but that's how I've got it to work. Let me know how you get on.
Cheers,
Steve

Hi Steve!
Thanks for your explanation! That the woven classes are not in the .jar but are actually duplicated to the output and "shaddowing" the original classes finally explained everything to me, like why "catching" those .jar's didn't change anything, etc.
It also made me aware that the build directory (or any .jar created from it) needs to come first in the classpath (they already were here, but it made me alert, that one needs to make sure, that this also remains so).
Starting from your list I also was finally able to understand my compile errors. Obviously the "normal" build (I mean the one automatically triggered by eclipse) uses the Java classpath. Here all my .jars were properly listed. That must have been, why compilation and execution in the runtime workbench worked. The build triggered by the "export..." however, seems to use the classpath listed in the plugin.xml's Runtime tab (lower right). Faithfully checking and duplicating all libraries there made all compile errors go away. That was problem one solved. Somehow, these two lists should be synchronized (or some warning, if they don't match), but I guess that wish should go into another bugzilla entry.
Once the compilation worked, the next problem was to make sure that all those duplicated files make it into the generated .zip file. This I achieved, by removing the "." from the classpath and replacing it with "build/", i.e. I am now explicitly adding the "build" directory to the plugin's classpath (in the first position to make sure, it properly shaddowes matching classes in the subsequent .jars). This causes the classpath to not start at the plugin's root directory (i.e. the top directory of the class file tree is now not "com" but in "build/com"), but so far I haven't noticed any problem with that.
With that, I can now export to plugin with AspectJ support and everything works as expected. I have to admit though, that this whole export process initially was not exactly intuitive. Some added remarks in the help that comes up when pressing the (?) at the lower right in the export wizard may be helpful. Especially that fact, that classes that are weaved (or woven?) are duplicated to the build diretory and one thus has to assure, that the *entire* build directory (not only the classes derived from source files) makes it into the generated .zip or .jar would be extremely helpful!
Cheers and thanks again for your support, Michael
We should update the docs to clarify this.

No problem Michael - I agree that it's all pretty confusing and a little help would be a very good thing. I'll be updating the docs, as Matt says.
I presume you mean "the help that comes up when pressing the (?) at the lower LEFT in the export wizard"? :-) "The other right" ;-)
Personally I'd never noticed this help feature before and it strikes me that it should be postioned somewhere else, maybe top right? Another topic, I know...

Created an attachment (id=55825) A docs patch (it changes an existing file, so I guess it's still a patch!) that describes how to work around this problem
It's pretty complicated and fiddly describing this problem and the solution, so I won't be surprised if someone wants to re-word this; it's the best that I could come up with after several attempts! I guess, as has been suggested, it would really be better if the export wizard just did the work for you. I notice there is a similar problem with the non-AspectJ plugin export... Anyhow, here's something for now.

(In reply to comment #4) > ... > I presume you mean "the help that comes up when pressing the (?) at the lower > LEFT in the export wizard"? :-) "The other right" ;-) > ...
yeah, right, it's left - uhm - I mean you are right that I meant left! ;-)
(In reply to comment #5)
Thanks for summarizing this! I'm sure it makes life easier for others and yourself, too (by saving you future explanations and newsgroup or bugzilla exchanges like this one ...).
Cheers and thanks, Michael
docs patch applied, with only minor edits - it does a good job of explaining this complex issue.

The docs have been updated as discussed, in:
1.5.0.20061218091526 (build.93)

bug.short_desc: Add CSPEC dependency prerequisites

long_desc.thetext:
Add the ability to express a prerequisite on a dependency in a cspec. The scenario is as follows (notation <c>#<a> means attribute <a> in component <c>):
Action X#A has a prerequisite to Attribute Y#B. Component Y is produced by(Z#C).
The current semantics only permit a dependency to an attribute in a specific component. It does not permit a declaration of an attribute that in itself represents a component. This can be expressed in the cspec by adding a prerequisite to the dependency. Like so:
<cs:cspec name="X"> <cs:dependencies> <cs:dependency name="Z"/> <cs:dependency name="Y"> <cs:attribute component="Z" name="C"/> </cs:dependency> </cs:dependencies>
<cs:actions> <cs:public name="A"> <cs:prerequisites> <cs:attribute component="Y" attribute="B"/> </cs:prerequisites> ... </cs:public> </cs:actions> ... </cs:cspec>
Expected flow: 1. Something triggers action X#A 2. Buckminster wants to resolve the prerequisite Y#B 3. It asks for the CSPEC of Y via the dependency 4. Finds the producedBy Z#C declaration 5. Z is brought in and the attribute C is requested 6. Z#C is somehow produced (if it is an action, it is executed) 7. Once completed, the Y CSPEC is obtained and returned all the way up 8. Y#B can now be resolved (which in turn might trigger actions in G)
I think the description is wrong. The XML shows <cs:attribute component="Z" name="C"/>, but the text talks about "producedBy" (step4). I think the XML example is in error.

I actually started off using 'producedBy' and also using wording like "an action that in itself produces a component". Then I realized that it doesn't have to be an action so I changed to "an attribute that in itself represents a component". I then changed the name of the XML element from 'producedBy' to 'representedBy', thought about that for a bit, then changed it to attribute.
My line of though is that the full meaning is 'representedByAttribute' and the 'representedBy' part becomes sort of implicit given the context where it is entered.

I do not agree - I think it is hard to read and understand. Now it looks like the dependency has an attribute. Here are some suggestions:
from component="Z" attribute="C" foundIn component="Z" attribute="C" obtainedFrom component="Z" attribute="C" in component="Z" attribute="C"
Also, why use name="C" instead of attribute="C"?

The answer to your last question is that it would be somewhat redundant to write <attribute attribute="C">.
But I agree. 'obtainedFrom' (my favourite among your suggestions) is a lot clearer then using 'attribute'. So if all in favor, I'll put that in instead.
oh, and then of course also use 'attribute' instead of 'name'.
ok, introduction to Buckminster now describes this using "obtained from"

"Obtained from" supplanted by new "generators" element. The idea is that a component that describes a dependency should not need any knowledge of how that dependency is resolved. Instead, this is described in an encompassing component that defines the resolution scope. Example:
<?xml version="1.0" encoding="UTF-8"?> <cspec xmlns="http://www.eclipse.org/buckminster/CSpec-1.0" name="org.eclipse.buckminster.ws" version="1.0.0" versionType="OSGi"> <generators> <generator generates="org.eclipse.buckminster.axis2" component="org.eclipse.buckminster.axis2.bundlegen" attribute="generate.bundle"/> </generators> <dependencies> <dependency name="org.eclipse.buckminster.axis2.bundlegen"/> <dependency name="org.eclipse.buckminster"/> </dependencies> </cspec>
Available since 1.0.0.v20070202

bug.short_desc: Regression: OwnerDrawLabelProvider no longer working

long_desc.thetext:
JFace running from Head
I am no longer able to use the OwnerDrawLabelProvider and the various snippets using it seem to fail as well.
The problem is, once you call ColumnViewer#setLabelProvider(), the OwnerDrawnLabelProvider gets wrapped around a DelegatingLabelProvider. However, in the callbacks of Custom-Owner-Drawn the labelprovider is asked to be an instance of OwnerDrawLabelProvider. This check fails.
This worked in M3 without problems.

This is duplicate of bug #166635. Please see my comments on this. I think we should not support provide the ability to use new functionality with the old API. This would mean that we need to refactor DecoratingLabelProvider no to extend CellLabelProvider.

I am fine with migrating the OwnerDrawLabelProvider to the new story as it was calling pakacge private code anyways.
Ben do you have any other feedback on the OwnerDraw support?
*** This bug has been marked as a duplicate of bug 166635 ***

Thanks for the clarification, makes sense.
The Custom-Owner-Drawn support in JFace looks really good so far. There is one thing consumers have to be aware of (thats what I had to figure out after a while):
If you call update() on a Viewer there is no 100% guarantee that one of the methods from OwnerDrawLabelProvider will be called at all. The reason for this is that the methods are only called from SWT when required. So, lets say you have a button left to a Tree that changes some kind of model once clicked. After the change, the Tree's content-provider will receive some kind of Model-Updated-Event and itself trigger an update to the Viewer. However, SWT would never call one of the COD-Methods, since nothing changed in the Widget so far.
First I thought it was a bug in SWT, because my Tree-Item updated only some Cells when updating my model, but then I found out that I was explicitly setting a Color to some Cells of the Tree due to the model-change. This made SWT trigger some of the COD-Methods, however invalidated only the regions the cells covered. So only parts of my TreeItems got updated.
My current workaround to this problem is to explicitly set a foreground-color to the entire TreeItem instead of a cell. That makes SWT invalidate the entire item and call the COD-Methods. An alternative would be to explicitly call Tree.redraw() with the treeitems-bounds, but thats somewhat ugly too.
Thanks Ben. Would you please log us another report about this issue (and any others) - I am currently the only one using this stuff and so we need to track things better.

Right. See Bug 166799
I am just beginning using the new API. I don't think there will be a lot more of bugs in JFace for COD, but I already filed some bugs that clearly belong to SWT :)
Ben

bug.short_desc: Binary Search Thread error when I close the project

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 3.2.1 M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Open an existing project and expand it (it will cause the Binary Search Thread to run); 2. On "C/C++ Projects" view, right click the project and select "Close Project", while the Binary Search Thread is still running; 3. Get the error message (which is attached).

bug.short_desc: number of matches for search results shall be shown for folders and projects

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: 4.0.0
Steps To Reproduce: When a search is made, CDT shows the search results in a tree view. This tree view includes files, folders and project itself. If there is only one match in one file, it is listed in this tree, if there are more than one matches, number of matches will be shown beside file name.
What we really need is to see the total number of matches under a folder. I beleive this can easily be shown near the folder name.
And also, if there is only one match, it will be better to write 1 match near the file name, instead of writing nothing.

bug.short_desc: [Aspects] Can't weave fragments

long_desc.thetext:
Bundle fragments are not woven because ClassLoadingHook.initializedClassLoader() is never called for the BundleData instance:
> AspectJAdaptor.initialize() bundle=update@plugins/org.eclipse.swt.win32.win32.x86_3.2.0.v3232m.jar, baseLoader=null W AspectJAdaptor.initialize() symbolicName=update@plugins/org.eclipse.swt.win32.win32.x86_3.2.0.v3232m.jar, baseLoader=null < AspectJAdaptor.initialize() weavingService=false, cachingService=false
Is this a Hooks bug or do I need to set the loader myself from the host bundle?

The javadoc is not clear, but the intention was that the initializedClassLoader would only be called for the host's BaseData object.
Can you give more details why you would need this called for fragment BaseData objects. The calls to ClassLoadingHook.processClass pass the BundleEntry (which may come from a fragment) and the ClasspathManager. You should be able to get the host BaseData and the BaseClassLoader from the ClasspathManager.

In AspectJ LTW we have ClassLoader <-> WeavingAdaptor -> Weaver -> World. Under OSGi things are more complex. We still need to use a class loader but things revolve around bundles and services: Bundle <-> BundleData <-> BundleFile -> AspectJAdaptor(ClassLoader) -> WeavingService(ClassLoader) -> WeavingAdaptor ... The lifecycle of the AspectJAdaptor highly asynchronous:
1. AspectJAdaptor(BaseData) [BundleFileWrapperFactoryHook.wrapBundleFile()] 2. setBaseLoader(BaseClassLoader) [ClassLoadingHook.initializedClassLoader()] 3. initialize() [ClassLoadingHook.initializedClassLoader()]
We initialize the adaptor on first reference i.e. when we try to weave the first class in a particular bundle. By that time we should have all the information we need to instantiate a weaving service in particular the bundle class loader. It is at this point we fail for fragments. I have only just discovered this problem when trying to weave some SWT classes that happen to reside in the win32 fragment.
I think this my problem because a fragment shares a class loader with its host so it should share a WeavingAdaptor and therefore probably a weaving service. When I create an AspectJAdaptor it should probably figure out that it's a fragment and get hold or the right weaving service.

perhaps speaking out of turn here but can the weaving focus on classloaders and use the rest of the context for scoping? That is, you hook a weaver into a classloader and then it can use the location of the class at hand (from a bundle, a fragment, etc) to determine higher level ideas of how, if, when an aspect should be applied? For example, I want to apply an aspect but only to a particular fragment of a particular host or just the host and not the fragments, or...

Not at all. I could probably, by using a separate weaver and world though a separate weaving service, scope an aspect to a fragment of the host but I'm not sure that it would be desirable. One example is that fragments are an extremely useful way of introducing an aspect into an existing bundle, so I definitely want the scope of an aspect to exceed the fragment that defines it. In which case I want to weave everything in that bundle including other fragments.
My understanding is that the contents of a fragment logically become part of the host: the manifests are merged and the classpath appended. At runtime a class can "see" every other class in the bundle including those in fragments and it can't tell where they came from: the PackageAdmin service will say it is the host (because it must use the defining class loader). I want aspects to behave like classes so they should "see" and therefore weave everything that is logically part of the bundle.
An interesting question.

Right. I was thinking that at the classloader level you can tell where a class is coming from because the classloader is in effect scanning the classpath (bundle itself, fragments etc) to find the .class file. You are absolutely right though that once a class is loaded you can't really tell where it came from (though that functionality could likely be implemented by replaying the class file lookup...)

While it would be possible to scope aspects along bundle-fragment and fragment-fragment boundaries I don't believe it would be useful. In my view fragments are an implementation detail that should not affect aspect scoping and would in fact prevent the application of some of the patterns I have been developing. The aspect writer already has the pointcut while the bundle writer has the aop.xml include/exclude elements to control scope.

Change AspectJAdaptor.initialize() to determine whether a bundle is in fact a fragment and if so obtain the weaving service for the host. Should probably use a separate caching service when implementing Bug 161023 "[Aspects] Phase III - Byte-code Caching".
Should I add weaving/not weaving messages for fragments and can't weave for org.aspectj bundles?
Fix available

bug.short_desc: [Aspects] No weaving unless configuration area cleared

long_desc.thetext: Unless "Clear the configuration area before launching" is checked on the "Configuration" tab of the launch configuration the AspectJ hook is loaded, weaving service started but no bundles are woven.

bug.short_desc: Teneo HibernatePersistableEList provides "bad" equals()
Please add RMAP provider extension

long_desc.thetext: There should be a RMAP extension point to make it possible to plug in a RMAP service. A property should control which such service is used by default.
As a consequence, I think a Provider needs to produce a Resolution with a different provider.

Added a new extension point 'org.eclipse.buckminster.core.queryResolvers' that makes it possible to register new Component Query Resolution strategies. An extension must implement the 'org.eclipse.buckminster.core.resolver.IResolverFactory' interface.

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: M20060921-0945
Steps To Reproduce: "Internal error" when trying to convert SDB to IBM rules using IBM JDK 1.42
How its been used... FastXPathAPI api = new FastXPathAPI(null); api.getFastXPathEngine().getExpressionJavaSource(XPATHExpression, cbe, true, null,null,new CompilerPostProcessor(null, null)
Calling FastXPathAPI api shown in the stack trace causing this error.
Extention point can't be use to get the FastXPathAPI object since it is protected.
Error does not occur when using IBM JDK 1.5
Stack trace: java.lang.LinkageError: JVMCL048:redefine of class TestXPath (&name=2C662598). old_cb=1397F68, new_cb=11448E8, (&old_name=2C662598) old_name=TestXPath at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass0(Native Method) at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java(Compiled Code)) at java.lang.ClassLoader.defineClass(ClassLoader.java:710) at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.provisional.fastxpath.compiler.EclipseCompiler$MyClassLoader.defineClass(EclipseCompiler.java:331) at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.provisional.fastxpath.compiler.EclipseCompiler$1.acceptResult(EclipseCompiler.java:119) at org.eclipse.jdt.internal.compiler.Compiler.compile(Compiler.java:417) at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.provisional.fastxpath.compiler.EclipseCompiler.generateClass(EclipseCompiler.java:131) at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.provisional.jre14.fastxpath.compiler.CompilerHelper.buildCompiledExpression(CompilerHelper.java:150) at org.eclipse.tptp.platform.provisional.jre14.fastxpath.FastXPathEngine.getExpressionJavaSource(FastXPathEngine.java:202) at

Targetting to 4.4

Same code was working in TPTP 4.2.0 Since TPTP has added performance fix for XPATH rules, this is been broken. I will make the change as you suggested. I am just wondering here that by doing what you are suggesting, is each xpath rule will create different class for it? Is this change will have any performance hit?

Praful from the code that I've seen you are creating a class anyway, my code snippet is only setting a different name to each new class. In 4.2 it worked because we were creating a class loader for each XPathExpression, we do reuse the class loader in 4.2.1.
Increasing priority as a major should be fixed in 4.4.
If bug 162562 will be fixed I will fix this also, if the compile code is removed I will return this defect as WONTFIX.
If this is fixed it will be fixed in the Fast XPATH implementation in the Platform.Models component.

bug.short_desc: [Decorators] Add a non-internal version of OverlayPreferenceStore

long_desc.thetext:
The platform currently contains three nearly identical copies of the class OverlayPreferenceStore, all of them internal to their respective plugins. This is actually a a useful utility class when creating preference pages (which is why several plugins need it) so there should be just one non-internal copy of this class.
I'll be happy to productize the code of one of the copies if you think this is a good idea.

I assume you mean OverlayCache? It is now backed by the much better ResourceManager so I don't think it is an interesting class anymore.
Check out ResourceManager for what you are after
Changing OS from Mac OS to Mac OS X as per bug 185991

bug.short_desc: SWT.Focused not send around in Custom-Owner-Drawn

long_desc.thetext: The SWT.FOCUSED detail bit is only set on an item if it is the focus item within the table/tree (ie.- it has the dots). If you want to know if the table/tree has focus then you can just use isFocusControl().
I see, thanks for the hint.

bug.short_desc: [api] Make DefaultCharacterPairMatcher.findPeer public

long_desc.thetext: The usual character matching method, DefaultCharacterPairMatcher.performMatch, allows you to find the matching peer for the character at a particular position. findPeer generalizes this by finding the matching peer for a user-specified character, starting from a particular position. This can be useful in situations such as auto edit where you're considering changes to a document that haven't actually been applied yet, so the character to find a peer for has not yet been inserted into the document.
There's no findPeer(...) method. Did you mean findMatchingPeer(...)? If so, this can't be made public since it needs the private DocumentPartitionAccessor which we don't want to make public.

It turns out that I had refactored the class and then forgotten about it. So let me rephrase the feature request.
I suggest that performMatch be refactored so that all code except for the first line is made into a new method (which could be called findPeer) that takes the document, offset and prevChar as arguments. This new method should be public for the reasons described in the original request.
I'd accept a good quality patch with some tests.

bug.short_desc: Custom-Drawing Selection-Color not working on col = 0 with sorting

long_desc.thetext: possibly related: bug 133161 and bug 156817

bug.short_desc: [variables] Copy variables shortcut key doesn't work after detail pane gets focus

long_desc.thetext:
Build ID: I20061129-1340
Steps To Reproduce: 1. Open variables view 2. Selecting variables and hitting Ctrl-C should copy the variables to the clipboard 3. Select text in the detail pane, Ctrl-C should copy the selected text to the clipboard 4. Select variables again. Hitting Ctrl-C does not copy.
More information: Due to the detail pane setting the copy action id to it's own text copy. When the variables tree regains focus it can't replace the text copy action with its own copy action because that action was added through plugin.xml.
Wait until 75852 is committed before altering how actions are handled in variables view.

Propose to have the detail pane proxy save/restore the global actions contributed to the action bars as the tree loses/gains focus, to restore all contributed actions and their global action definition ids.

The action bar does not have access to all contributed actions - only the actions on the toolbar (i.e. not the copy action in the context menu).
For now, we save/restore the copy action in the variable view.
Fixed. Please verify, Curtis.

Verified the fix
In the future we should look at ways of improving the action handling in the variables view to allow more flexibility for plugin contributed actions. Requiring actions to be hard coded to get/keep key bindings could be a problem.

bug.short_desc: variables in config.ini template field don't stick

long_desc.thetext:
I20061128-0800
If you use a variable to point to a config.ini template in the workspace (i.e. ${workspace_loc}\demo.eclipse.tracing\config.ini) then PDE seems to fill in the correct information when you launch. But then if you open the launcher again you will notice that the ${workspace_loc} variable has been replaced with the real absolute path to your workspace. All other fields in PDE seem to keep the variable and do not modify the value with the real path.
I ran into this issue following the instructions at the AspectJ incubator site http://www.eclipse.org/equinox/incubator/aspects/getting_started.php
The demos in the incubator include launchers that point to workspace config.ini templates. The problem is the launchers include absolute paths the the workspace the developer was using when they specified the launchers. It would be nice if these launchers could be released with ${workspace_loc} variables but PDE UI prevents this.

I have encountered this problem myself but never got around to reporting it (sigh). I have tried to ensure the launch configurations work by hacking the file but PDE overwrites it if you make any changes through the wizard so I miss some (argh). It's a pain because .launch files are supposed to be shared and are a nice way of encapsulating complexity like config.ini.
Done, will be in 3.3M4

bug.short_desc: Add org to .cvsignore

long_desc.thetext:
From Ed Merks:
I need you to add org to .cvsignore in org.eclipse.gef and org.eclipse.draw2d. Each change is simply adding the "org" folder to the root .cvsignore for the project;
The reason for these changes is that we bootstrap our main Eclipse development environment as described in Bug 109137. This involves either building the jar specified in the MANIFEST.MF, or if it specifies ".", copying the contents of the bin folder to the root of the project.
In either case, unless the .cvsignore says to ignore this generated result, I end up with a CVS delta for each non-EMF/UML project I have in my workspace which consists of 167 projects by the time I include GEF, GMF, and so on. Right now, as I'm doing the Java 5.0 changes, I'm monitoring the impact on downstream plugins so that I can provide patches to fix the small number of source incompatibilities that are showing up and this large list of bogus deltas has gotten really annoying.
Committed the fix.

bug.short_desc: [Viewers] ColumnViewer#update() is not calling OwnerDrawLabelProvider methods in most cases

long_desc.thetext:
The Custom-Owner-Drawn support in JFace looks really good so far. There is one thing consumers have to be aware of (thats what I had to figure out after a while):
If you call update() on a Viewer there is no 100% guarantee that one of the methods from OwnerDrawLabelProvider will be called at all. The reason for this is that the methods are only called from SWT when required. So, lets say you have a button left to a Tree that changes some kind of model once clicked. After the change, the Tree's content-provider will receive some kind of Model-Updated-Event and itself trigger an update to the Viewer. However, SWT would never call one of the COD-Methods, since nothing changed in the Widget so far.
First I thought it was a bug in SWT, because my Tree-Item updated only some Cells when updating my model, but then I found out that I was explicitly setting a Color to some Cells of the Tree due to the model-change. This made SWT trigger some of the COD-Methods, however invalidated only the regions the cells covered. So only parts of my TreeItems got updated.
My current workaround to this problem is to explicitly set a foreground-color to the entire TreeItem instead of a cell. That makes SWT invalidate the entire item and call the COD-Methods. An alternative would be to explicitly call Tree.redraw() with the treeitems-bounds, but thats somewhat ugly too.
Sorry, this one fell between the cracks for 3.3.

bug.short_desc: [ErrorHandling] The Status Handling hooking into Eclipse

long_desc.thetext: Created an attachment (id=55048) The Handling in Jobs and JFace

Questions to the patch
1. The methods openWarning and openError in the MessageDialog class from jface don't show dialogs now. They create statuses and pass them to the logger from the policy. Is it ok?
Alternative solution is that these methods can open dialogs if default logger is set, or I can have another logger used only in these two methods? What do you think?
2. In ProgressManager method crateChangeListener(). There is JobChangeAdapter and done() method. Is FinishedJobs.getInstance().remove(info) ok? Or maybe I have to remove JobInfo from FinishedJobs using commented code with iterator?
Created an attachment (id=55116) The Handling in Jobs, JFace and parts opening

4) You might want to use a utility class to do handleException and handleStatus > rather than the plug-in. Maybe in StatusUtil or something you have in your new > code.
If we put it to the WorkbenchPlugin we can use it like log() methods and we don't have to care about pluginId.
> 5)We need to remove the commented out code in the ProgressManager of course but > thanks for the explanation. > We should not play with FinishedJobs with anything more than remove(info). If > there is some tidying up we can do it.
ok
> 6) Why did > > jobs.remove(event.getJob()); > // Only refresh if we are showing it > removeJobInfo(info); > > get moved up? I want to be sure there is not anything subtle about moving this > - I wrote the code so long ago that I am always concerned about changes for no > reason. >
It is because this adds jobs to the FinishedJobs. If want to remove jobs from FinishedJobs, we have to have
jobs.remove(event.getJob()); // Only refresh if we are showing it removeJobInfo(info);
first.

>If we put it to the WorkbenchPlugin we can use it like log() methods >and we don't have to care about pluginId.
log() is API defined on Plugin. The only code that accesses the WorkbenchPlugin is workbench code so there is no need for any symettry as it is not API.
The other comments are good for me. Looks like you found a bug in the ProgressManager.
Created an attachment (id=55142) The Handling in Jobs, JFace and parts opening
Created an attachment (id=55143) The Handling in Jobs, JFace and parts opening
Point 2 is an issue but otherwise this looks OK for me. Fix that up and we'll have Paul take a look.

I took the liberty of externalizing the status string in the IDEExceptionHandler as it wasn't clear to me that the user would never see it but I have otherwise released the patch.
Szymon please find something Paul can look at as these time critical fixes always end up committed by me.
This fix caused a major regression. See bug 168720 for the details. A temporary fix has been released to HEAD.
